componenttext: And that does conclude today's conference. Thank you for your participation today.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Electronic Arts Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. For opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call to Mary Vegh, Manager of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Electronic Arts Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. For opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call to Mary Vegh, Manager of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dustin. Thank you all for joining us this afternoon. Welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call. Today on the call, we have John Riccitiello, our Chief Executive Officer; Eric Brown, our Chief Financial Officer; and John Schappert, Chi
componenttext: Thanks, Dustin. Thank you all for joining us this afternoon. Welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call. Today on the call, we have John Riccitiello, our Chief Executive Officer; Eric Brown, our Chief Financial Officer; and John Schappert, Chief Operating Officer. Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that you may find copies of our SEC filings, our earnings release and a replay of this webcast on our website at investor.ea.com. Shortly after the call, we will post a copy of our prepared remarks on our website. Throughout this call, we will present both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures. Our earnings release provides a reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP measures. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to be considered in isolation from, a substitute for, or superior to our GAAP results, and we encourage investors to consider all measures before making an investment decision. All comparisons made in the course of this call are against the same period for the prior year, unless otherwise stated. Please see the supplemental information on our website for our trailing 12-month segment shares, additional GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations, a summary of our financial guidance and our title slate. During the course of this call, we may make forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance of the company. We caution you that actual events and results may differ materially. We refer you to our most recent Form 10-Q for a discussion of risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those discussed today. We make these statements as of February 8, 2010, and disclaim any duty to update them. Now I would like to turn the call over to John.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary. Earlier today, we announced our Q3 results, which were in line with the update we provided on January 11. We also provided our FY '11 guidance, which, at the midpoint of our range, translates to more than a 40% increase in non-GAAP EPS. O
componenttext: Thank you, Mary. Earlier today, we announced our Q3 results, which were in line with the update we provided on January 11. We also provided our FY '11 guidance, which, at the midpoint of our range, translates to more than a 40% increase in non-GAAP EPS. On today's call, I'll begin with brief comments in our progress, Eric will review the Q3 results and review our guidance in detail. John Schappert will provide an operations update, and then we'll take your questions.Let me start with an update on EA's execution framed against the four strategic initiatives we have identified as crucial to our long-term growth and profitability. First, product quality. In calendar '09, we shipped 19 titles with a Metacritic rating of 80 or better, the next best third-party publisher shipped only six. We also just shipped Mass Effect 2 with a Metacritic rating of 96, one of the highest-rated games ever released on Xbox 360. EA is clearly the quality leader among multi-platform publishers. I believe this is a significant driver in the fact that EA has gained share, fiscal year to date.Second, creating hits in core packaged goods. We're very proud that both Madden and FIFA remained at the top of the charts again in calendar '09. We're also pleased that we've established two new eyepiece, a sequel-ready successes so far this fiscal year in Dragon Age and EA SPORTS Active, that our recent win with Mass Effect suggests these three titles can be sequel successfully in the future.Third, our investment in Digital revenue stream meeting, and in many cases, exceeding our own high expectations. We achieved a record $152 million in quarterly non-GAAP net revenue in Q3. This brings us to 30% growth in Digital revenue in fiscal year to date. Our overall Digital business is now at scale over $500 million annually, growing very rapidly and profitable.Lastly, operating efficiencies. In the past two years, we have dramatically lowered headcount despite acquisitions and the addition of multiple Digital business models. Our operating costs are expected to be down on FY '10 versus FY '09, and down even further in FY '11. With that, I will turn it over to Eric.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. First, EA's Q3 together with our guidance for Q4 is at the lower end of the range we guided on January 11. While we are very pleased with the performance per title so far in the fourth quarter, we remain cautious in the packaged goods mar
componenttext: Thank you, John. First, EA's Q3 together with our guidance for Q4 is at the lower end of the range we guided on January 11. While we are very pleased with the performance per title so far in the fourth quarter, we remain cautious in the packaged goods market that remains soft overall and hit driven. Second, our guidance for F '11 is framed by three major considerations. While we see reasons for optimism for the packaged goods sector, we believe using a minus 3% rate for the sector is a better planning assumption. We've made the call to deemphasize low-margin distribution in our FY '11 guidance, which reduces top line revenue but has limited effect in earnings. While there may be the occasional distribution deal that meets our criteria going forward, part of our mantra, fewer and bigger, since the recognition that tighter focus will yield better results. Lastly, we note that we've built a plan around an expense base that is approximately $100 million lower in F '11 than F '10 and like-on-like, adjusting for foreign exchange bonus and Playfish run rate is approximately $200 million lower on a non-GAAP basis.By driving down expenses aggressively, we're able to guide to non-GAAP EPS growth of 40% at the mid-point of our guidance range, while maintaining a realistic stance on the packaged goods sector. I will now provide industry comments and then turn to EA results. For Western markets overall, the packaged goods sector was down 9% in the quarter versus expectations of a flat quarter. Both North America and Europe were down 9%. Europe's biggest market, the U.K., was down 16% year-over-year.In the quarter, Sony PS3 hardware sales increased 48% year-over-year, Wii hardware sales decreased 2% year-over-year, while Xbox 360 hardware sales declined 21% year-over-year. Hardware sales responded to price promotions, particularly the Wii in North America with Wal-Mart promoting the Wii at an effective $149 price point. In North America, concentration of sales in the top titles continued, with the top 20 titles in calendar Q4 '09, representing 48% share in dollars versus 37% share in calendar Q4 '06.For the global market including Asia, we estimate that total packaged goods represented approximately 60% of the overall software market for calendar 2009, while total Digital, consisting of mobile and online, was approximately 40%. While packaged goods were down 9% in calendar '09, we estimate that total Digital increased by approximately 28%, growing the combination of packaged goods plus Digital by 3% year-over-year.EA's fiscal third quarter results were in line with the update we provided on our January 11, 2010 call. Non-GAAP net revenue was $1.346 billion, short of our going-in expectations due to a soft December for EA and the weak overall packaged goods sector. We also experienced product mix shift to lower margin distribution titles in the December quarter in North America. On a GAAP basis, net revenue was $1.243 billion. At constant currency rates, net revenue decreased $435 million or 25% year-over-year. The primary cause of change year-over-year was the greater number of front-line titles like Need for Speed, Mirror's Edge and Dead Space in Q3 fiscal '09.In our Packaged Goods business, FIFA 10 sold through over 7 million copies at retail in the quarter for Europe and North America combined, and launched with a Metacritic rating of 91 on the PS3 and Xbox 360. In Europe, it was the number two title across all platforms in the quarter, and the number two title in calendar '09. Madden NFL 10 sold through over 2.3 million copies at retail in the quarter. In North America, Madden NFL 10 charted number four overall in calendar '09. Year-over-year, Madden sales in all platforms combined continue to close the gap in North America from minus 17% through Q2 to minus 6% through the end of Q3. Our core platforms, PS3 and Xbox 360, are up 15% on a cumulative basis.Dragon Age: Origins was a key front-line title for the quarter. It sold in 2.7 million copies worldwide on the PC, PS3 and Xbox 360 platforms, and received a Metacritic rating of 88 across all platforms. In our Distribution business, Left 4 Dead 2 in partnership with Valve exceeded our expectations with 2.9 million copies sold in worldwide on the PC and Xbox 360 during the holiday quarter, and it charted in the top 10 in North America according to NPD. In our Digital business, FIFA 10 with its innovative Ultimate Team mode, Dragon Age premium digital content, Battlefield 1943 and The Sims Store all performed well in the quarter. Pogo continues to be the number one online game site worldwide in terms of user engagement. We started recognizing Playfish revenue in the fiscal third quarter. During Q3, we had two of the top 10 Facebook games.We continue to be the number one mobile games provider in Western markets. We had seven of the top 11 games in December for the iPhone and four of the top five selling games for 2009. EA had seven of the top 10 games on Verizon during the quarter, and achieved over 50% of the top 10 games on AT&T, Sprint and T-Mobile.We had 1.9 million total subscribers in the quarter. This includes Pogo, as well as massively multi-player online or MMO subscribers. We finished the quarter with 49 million registered users, and our central user identity management system up 16% from the prior quarter. This includes console and PC users. Performance by Digital business model included the following for the quarter: We achieved another record quarter with $152 million in non-GAAP Digital net revenue, up 30% year-over-year; Mobile revenue was $57 million, up 14% year-over-year; Digital revenue from all other non-mobile sources was $95 million for the quarter, up 42% year-over-year. This includes full game downloads, PC and console premium downloadable content or PDLC, browser games, subscriptions, social games and advertising.Moving to the rest of the income statement, non-GAAP gross profit margin was 51.6% versus 47.1% a year ago. This is up from the prior year due to a greater mix of published titles. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $540 million, down $47 million or 8% year-over-year. Total bonus accrued as of the end of Q3 is $54 million compared with $43 million through Q3 last year. Total variable market expense in the quarter was $149 million compared with $187 million in the same quarter last year, which is in line with a different title plan where we had more front-line releases last year. Non-GAAP operating income was $154 million versus non-GAAP operating income of $234 million a year ago.Below the operating income line, non-GAAP other income and expense was negative $2 million versus positive $14 million a year ago. This reduction is due to lower cash balances and the $7 million adverse foreign currency movement compared to a year ago. On a GAAP basis, we recorded a tax benefit of $28 million, primarily due to a reduction in our deferred tax valuation allowance related to the change in U.S. tax law for tax laws secured backs. On a non-GAAP basis, we reported taxes at 28%. GAAP diluted loss per share was $0.25 versus a diluted loss per share of $2 a year ago. Last year, we recorded a significant goodwill impairment and tax valuation allowance charge in Q3. Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.33 versus diluted earnings per share of $0.56 a year ago. In Q3, we generated $221 million of operating cash flow versus $212 million a year ago. Fiscal year to date, our operating cash flow improved by $102 million versus last year. We ended the quarter with 8,537 employees versus 9,760 a year ago. 20% of our employees are now in low-cost locations versus 17% a year ago.Turning to the balance sheet, cash and short-term investments were approximately $1.466 billion at quarter end, down approximately $159 million from last quarter, primarily due to the acquisition of Playfish. Marketable equity securities was $318 million, down $69 million from last quarter, primarily due to the sale of benign shares and a decline in the value of our Ubisoft investment. At quarter end, we had $179 million of net unrealized gains on investments. Gross accounts receivable were $762 million, down $335 million from last year or down 31%. DSOs were 51 days versus 57 last year. Reserves against outstanding receivables totaled $267 million, down $36 million from a year ago. Reserve levels were 8% of trailing nine-month non-GAAP revenue versus 9% a year ago.Inventory was $144 million, down $151 million from a year ago. Ending deferred net revenue from Packaged Goods and Digital Content was $895 million, up $383 million from a year ago due to the additional deferral for all console and online-enabled PC games. Restructuring update. Our restructuring plan is on track. During Q3, we recorded $96 million of restructuring expense for our fiscal '10 restructuring plan of the estimated total amount of $150 million to $155 million. We closed five locations and are approximately 2/3 complete with position reductions at the end of January 2010.Now to our outlook for Q4 fiscal '10. Revenue. On a GAAP basis, we expect revenue of $925 million to $1 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect revenue of $800 million to $850 million. Operating expenses. We expect GAAP operating expenses to be approximately $625 million to $640 million and non-GAAP operating expenses of approximately $520 million to $535 million. Below the line, we expect GAAP diluted EPS of $0.05 to $0.23. We expect non-GAAP EPS of $0.02 to $0.06. For taxes, we expect a GAAP tax expense of approximately $0 million to $10 million, excluding the impact of tax-related charges that may arise in connection with the Playfish integration. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect to report taxes at 28%. For share count, please use 328 million shares to compute both GAAP and non-GAAP EPS.FY '11 outlook and guidance. As we go through our fiscal '11 guidance, we will refer to three principal lines of business. First, packaged goods, this includes higher margin EA-owned titles and co-published titles. PC titles like The Sims 3 can yield up to a 90% gross profit margin and owned console products typically yield 60% to 70% gross profit margins. Distribution, this includes third-party titles distributed by EA yielded in net margin, typically in the teen percent range. Digital, this is the aggregation of our online, global and digital products and services. The business units at scale in our portfolio like Pogo and Mobile have pro-forma operating margins of 20% or more.For fiscal '11, we are making the following assumptions. Sector. Our guidance is based on an assumption that total worldwide Packaged Goods will be down 3% in calendar year 2010. We are projecting continued robust growth in Digital of approximately 26%, which is expected to grow the composite sector by 8% for calendar 2010. While there is a possibility of software catalysts, including A, a strong industry title slate, B,  growth coming from the introduction of Microsoft and Sony motion controllers and C, growth coming from potential console price reductions in calendar '10, we are not counting on Packaged Goods software growth in our fiscal '11 plan.Total EA. We expect to end fiscal '10 with a total of approximately 8,120 headcount. We expect to end fiscal '11 with roughly the same total headcount. Total low-cost location headcount is increasing from approximately 21% or 1,800 pre-restructuring at the end of Q2 to 2,100 or 26% at the end of fiscal '11. For exchange rates, we are assuming $1.43 U.S. to the euro, $0.95 U.S. to the Canadian dollar and $1.60 U.S. to the British pound. Currency markets are still volatile, and our R&D costs will increase if the Canadian dollar strengthens.Packaged goods. Our fiscal '11 plan currently includes a total of 36 titles for the fiscal year versus 54 in fiscal '10. This number excludes expansion packs. Our top 20 titles for fiscal '11 are expected to generate approximately 80% of total non-distribution packaged goods revenue. This compares to an estimated 76% for the top 20 titles in fiscal '10. We have included a fiscal '11 title plan with our earnings press release, which details our principal titles, including digital games for console and PC. Our total variable marketing and advertising in fiscal '11 is an estimated $475 million to $495 million, which is comparable to the total amount for fiscal '10. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect fiscal '11 revenue from EA-published packaged goods titles to be between $2.75 billion to $3 billion, which reflects flat share at the middle of the range. Distribution. While we have great relationships with our partners, we are modeling the reduction in our Distribution business as we concentrate on higher margin EA-owned titles and digital initiatives. This will result in a $450 million year-over-year reduction in expected Distribution revenue.Digital. We are not assuming that we bring a major new MMO to market in fiscal '11. We will continue to incur significant development costs as we prepare this title for launch. In fiscal '11, we will continue to introduce new service and product features that benefit unique registered purchasers on PC and console games. Our most recent example is the Cerberus Content Network introduced with Mass Effect 2. We are planning a number of digital launches in fiscal '11, including Tiger Woods Online, going from beta to full launch, FIFA Online and Need for Speed World. We expect to launch a similar number of mobile and social network games compared to fiscal '10.We expect to grow our total Digital direct revenue by 30% or more from approximately $575 million in fiscal '10 to at least $750 million in fiscal '11. The year-over-year dollar growth is expected to be comprised of 1/4 from console full games and PDLC, 1/4 from PC and browser full games and PDLC, and 1/2 from games services and advertising, which includes Playfish, social games, Pogo, mobile and subscriptions.Q1 fiscal '11 guidance. Revenue. On a GAAP basis, we expect revenue of $710 million to $750 million. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect revenue of $460 million to $500 million. Q1 revenue is down year-over-year as we are comparing to a Q1 last year that included The Sims 3 and EA SPORTS Active launches. The Q1 fiscal '11 title slate includes FIFA World Cup, Skate 3, Tiger PGA Tour and The Sims 3 expansion pack. There's a total of four front-line titles compared to 10 front-line titles last year. Looking at Q1 year-over-year, World Cup comp's active, and there are no Q1 fiscal '11 comps for Harry Potter and The Sims 3. Below the line, we expect GAAP EPS ranging from a loss per share of $0.05 to a profit of $0.05 per share. We expect non-GAAP loss per share of $0.35 to $0.40. Fiscal '11 full year guidance. Revenue. On a GAAP basis, we expect revenue of $3.45 billion to $3.7 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect total revenue of $3.65 billion to $3.9 billion. Breaking this down into three components, we expect Digital revenue of $750 million or more in fiscal '11. We expect approximately $160 million in Distribution revenue, which is a $450 million year-over-year decrease. And we expect Packaged Goods revenue ranging from approximately $2.75 billion to $3 billion. Gross margins. We expect GAAP gross profit margins of approximately 57% to 58% and non-GAAP gross profit margins of approximately 60%. Operating expenses. We expect GAAP operating expenses to be approximately $2.3 billion and non-GAAP operating expenses of approximately $2 billion. Absolute non-GAAP operating expenses are down $100 million overall. On a like-on-like basis, operating expenses are down approximately $200 million year-over-year, if we adjust for the impact of foreign exchange, the assumption of full bonus and the impact of the Playfish expenses. The $200 million savings compares favorably to the $100 million net savings expectations we communicated when we announced our fiscal '10 restructuring plan. At the bottom line, we expect GAAP diluted loss per share of $0.60 to $0.90. We expect to be profitable and generate non-GAAP EPS of $0.50 to $0.70. We expect that non-GAAP other income and expense would be approximately $5 million. We expect our GAAP tax rate will continue to be volatile on an absolute dollar basis and subject to changes in the business or the tax laws. We expect tax expense ranging from $30 million to $40 million. We expect GAAP losses in fiscal '11, creating additional valuation allowances on U.S. deferred tax assets. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect to report taxes at 28%. For share count, please use 328 million shares to compute the GAAP loss per share and 330 million shares to compute non-GAAP EPS.Fiscal '11 revenue phasing. We currently expect the total of 36 front-line titles shipping in fiscal '11 versus 54 in fiscal '10. By quarter, we currently expect the following number of titles to ship in fiscal '11: Q1, four titles; Q2, nine titles; Q3, 14 titles; and Q4, nine titles. I'd like to remind everyone that last year's first fiscal quarter had unusually high revenue due to the launch schedule and the additional week of reported business. We expect fiscal '11's quarterly revenue phasing to be more consistent with prior years with non-GAAP revenue distributed as follows: Q1, approximately 30%; Q2, approximately 25%; Q3, approximately 40%; and Q4, approximately to 20% to 25%. This concludes our outlook and guidance. And with that, I'll turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, John Schappert.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. I would like to update you on our titles for Q4 fiscal '10 and in turn, our plans to FY '11. I'll start by highlighting three of our biggest titles in the current quarter. BioWare's Mass Effect 2 shipped January 26 on Xbox 360 and PC to reco
componenttext: Thanks, Eric. I would like to update you on our titles for Q4 fiscal '10 and in turn, our plans to FY '11. I'll start by highlighting three of our biggest titles in the current quarter. BioWare's Mass Effect 2 shipped January 26 on Xbox 360 and PC to record pre-orders and record-setting quality. 40 critics gave it a perfect 10, and the game launched with a Metacritic rating of 96. We backed it with a big marketing campaign, and we're very pleased with both the quality and consumer response on this one. We announced the shipment of 2 million copies and the early read on sell-through is strong. Dante's Inferno from our Visceral studio ships tomorrow, February 9, on PS3, Xbox 360 and PSP. We have another strong marketing campaign for Dante's, including our first ever Super Bowl ad, which aired yesterday. We saw more than 3 million downloads of our demo, pre-orders are tracking well and we're eager for the launch this week.Battlefield: Bad Company 2 from our DICE Studio ships March 2 on Xbox 360, PS3 and PC. Early feedback from critics has been very positive, and we're very excited about this title. Now I'd like to sketch some of the product highlights for fiscal '11. Included in our earnings release is a table that shows you most, but not all of the titles we are planning for the fiscal year, as well as preliminary platform plans and estimated launch window. And while this list shows some of our big launches, it does not reflect the large and growing revenue we hope to see from digital opportunities like Playfish and mobile, from online games like FIFA Online, or from post-launch downloadable content we offer with most of our games. So while this list can inform your modeling, it is by no means a complete look at EA's overall opportunity. With that, here are a few highlights, starting with Q1. 2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa, as fan excitement builds for the world's biggest sporting event, our game will feature all the teams from qualifying nations and authentic online tournament mode. Next, Skate 3 is an award-winning new franchise that has gone head to head with an old competitor, AND1 [ph]. This year's Skate 3 will include a co-op skateboarding experience and online features that allow players to form teams and compete against rival crews. Also in Q1, is Tiger Woods PGA TOUR '11. I should also mention that our web-based Tiger Woods PGA TOUR online game recently went into open beta, and offers a terrific online experience.And finally, Need for Speed World is a web-based, open-world game with licensed cars, extensive game modes and a massive online environment. This game will launch in open beta in the quarter. In Q2, we are laying down some big bets with blockbusters from EA SPORTS and the EA Games label. I'll start with the North American flagships, NCAA Football 11 and Madden NFL 11, and of course, the world's most beautiful game, FIFA 11. We will also be bringing FIFA Online to the Western world, a totally web-based expense that has been extremely popular in Asian markets. And finally from EA SPORTS, the franchise that won so much recognition from critics, NHL 11. My final callout for Q2 is the return of Medal of Honor. This great franchise is leading World War II and taking players directly into today's war in Afghanistan. I saw the demo last week, and this one is shaping up to be terrific. Now on to Q3, our holiday quarter. EA SPORTS Active for the Wii was one of EA's most successful new franchises in 2009, will back in 2010 but this time across multiple platforms. Also from EA SPORTS in Q3, NBA Live 11, and you'll see the return of arcade favorite, NBA Jam. Next, one of the most anticipated new properties of the year, EA SPORTS MMA. Our mixed martial arts game will feature an array of the top fighters and fighting styles. Also in the holiday quarter, The Sims 3 is coming to console. we're also launching a new Harry Potter title, a new action based Need for Speed from our Criterion studio and several offerings for kids and families from our partnership with Hasbro.Another game for the holiday is Crysis 2 from our partners at Crytek. This is a publishing agreement with full EA margins, issued or based in New York City and is coming to both consoles and the PC. And finally, Q4, Winter of 2011 marks the chilling return of Dead Space, a highly rated, wholly owned the franchise, another big driving simulation from Need for Speed, a new shooter being developed by Epic studios and co-published by EA, and finally, something far-reaching from Mass Effect. That's a look at some of our big title launches for both packaged goods and online. In fiscal '11, everyone of EA's releases will have an online component, both downloadable content and online play. And don't forget that we have a full roster of titles coming from our online subscription site, pogo.com, from our mobile and iPhone group, and of course, our social gaming team, Playfish. That's a lot of exciting content and revenue opportunities coming through all three of our businesses, Packaged Goods, Digital and Distribution. With that, I'll turn the call back over to John.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. We have an outstanding portfolio of IP that is getting stronger with the addition of Dragon Age, Mass Effect, EA SPORTS Active and the reinvigoration of key franchises like Need for Speed, Battlefield and FIFA. And while EA's IP portfolio wa
componenttext: Thanks, John. We have an outstanding portfolio of IP that is getting stronger with the addition of Dragon Age, Mass Effect, EA SPORTS Active and the reinvigoration of key franchises like Need for Speed, Battlefield and FIFA. And while EA's IP portfolio was described by some as tired a few short years ago, it has now a major competitive advantage. Our Packaged Goods business is performing. We have gained market share this fiscal year as a result of great quality and improved marketing. In fiscal '11, we believe titles like Medal of Honor, Crysis 2, Dead Space, The Sims 3 on console and others have break-out potential. We have a profitable scale Digital business that recently hit the $500 million threshold. Our Digital business is growing at 30% and is projected to break through three quarters at $1 billion in fiscal '11. We have programs in place that should take just to well beyond $1 billion in the coming two fiscal years. John, Eric and I will now be happy to take your questions.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Brian Pitz with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Brian Pitz with UBS.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on the overall industry weakness then some of the numbers you gave, with high ratios down, do you think this is really a cyclical issue? Or do you think gamers are starting to become different in terms of their daily behavior, so they're more dis
componenttext: Question on the overall industry weakness then some of the numbers you gave, with high ratios down, do you think this is really a cyclical issue? Or do you think gamers are starting to become different in terms of their daily behavior, so they're more distracted by social apps and games, mobile apps, the iPhone, iPod, iPad, all the other devices out there and just having general less time for games? And is this potentially a more of a secular issue longer term?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is John. First up, we do have data and research on the amount of time consumers are spending with games. And increasingly and importantly, they're spending more time with their console than they ever had before. So I don't think it's a consume
componenttext: Brian, this is John. First up, we do have data and research on the amount of time consumers are spending with games. And increasingly and importantly, they're spending more time with their console than they ever had before. So I don't think it's a consumer behavior issue if it's anything at all. And I do think it's fair to characterize 2009 as being a consequence of a relatively less powerful slate industrywide compared to 2008. I think the second factor, and I've pointed this before in 2009, was sort of a lack of aggressive pricing on first party, sort of if you will, a little bit too late with their price cuts, and frankly and broadly, the economic circumstance and if you will, the recession that hit in most Western markets or all Western markets. Net-net time, is up. The market was soft for the reasons I just identified. As we look to 2010, there's nothing that suggest that consumers aren't going to continue to increase use of their console. Relative to others that have provided guidance for the year, we've decided to be a little bit more conservative. And frankly, that's a function of the fact that we haven't seen enough data that suggest that the purchase behaviors are there yet in Spain. What makes us feel good about it, though, is if there's a strong slate, we've got a strong belief in new motion controllers. So there's reason to be optimistic. We just chose to not give, I think it's a better planning assumption to be more conservative here.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you go with a more conservative outlook than you have in the past?
componenttext: So you go with a more conservative outlook than you have in the past?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's it. It's definitely not time or consumer behavior to be clear. While we see growth in Digital, I don't see any data that suggest that digital offerings are causing the core gamer to spend less time with their console.
componenttext: That's it. It's definitely not time or consumer behavior to be clear. While we see growth in Digital, I don't see any data that suggest that digital offerings are causing the core gamer to spend less time with their console.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Jess Lubert with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Jess Lubert with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you provide some additional insight regarding your pricing assumptions for fiscal 2011? Should we expect to see a greater number of titles at sub-59, 99 price points? And does your current guidance assume accelerated price degradation versus prior yea
componenttext: Can you provide some additional insight regarding your pricing assumptions for fiscal 2011? Should we expect to see a greater number of titles at sub-59, 99 price points? And does your current guidance assume accelerated price degradation versus prior years? Or do you expect the pricing environment to remain relatively consistent? And then, also, you gave a pretty detailed title breakdown for the year, can you maybe highlight which of each of these titles is for Natal and which is for Arc? Am I right in thinking you won't release any Rock Band title in fiscal '11?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple, three questions there. I think we'll probably split this one up. In terms of pricing, I would tell you that I really can't give you any insight into our forward pricing assumptions that we've said many times on these calls. That's between us and
componenttext: A couple, three questions there. I think we'll probably split this one up. In terms of pricing, I would tell you that I really can't give you any insight into our forward pricing assumptions that we've said many times on these calls. That's between us and our retailers, and there's a variety of regulatory reasons why we're not able to do that. If you did want to pick up sort of an interesting analysis, I would encourage you to look at data from NPD for example. In 2003, peak of last cycle to 2009 sort of the current -- the most recent year, which is end of the six-year split, I think you'll see as when you look at sort of top 10, top 20, top 30, about a $10 to $12 pickup in pricing, suggestive of the fact that the top titles sold very well at top prices. And at least on a historic basis, there's very little that suggest that hasn't been the case nor that it won't be continually be the case.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to the motion controller games on -- it's all on XBOX and the Sony motion controller, we will be supporting both of those platforms at launch. We don't have any titles to announce right now on those, but we will be supporting those titles and
componenttext: With respect to the motion controller games on -- it's all on XBOX and the Sony motion controller, we will be supporting both of those platforms at launch. We don't have any titles to announce right now on those, but we will be supporting those titles and we are hopeful on those. The last question was on Rock Band. We have a -- our deal with Viacom and Harmonix continues through FY '11. At that time, as you see from our modeling, we have not included a lot of revenue for distribution next year. But we continue to have talks with them and hope that maybe there's an opportunity to continue the relationship beyond that.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is John. Just clarifying, which I meant was our relationship is defined through FY '10 for new frontline releases. We've got a strong relationship and we haven't incorporated it in but we don't presently have an agreement for FY ‘11 new titles.
componenttext: This is John. Just clarifying, which I meant was our relationship is defined through FY '10 for new frontline releases. We've got a strong relationship and we haven't incorporated it in but we don't presently have an agreement for FY ‘11 new titles.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Natal and Arc titles will be incremental to the slate provided?
componenttext: And Natal and Arc titles will be incremental to the slate provided?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, they're included in the slate provided.
componenttext: No, they're included in the slate provided.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Edward Williams with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Edward Williams with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an idea as to how much of your R&D budget is tied to games that are shipping in FY '12 or beyond? I'm just trying to get a handle around the size of the budget currently allocated to the Star Wars MMO and how that may differ in FY '11, and
componenttext: Can you give us an idea as to how much of your R&D budget is tied to games that are shipping in FY '12 or beyond? I'm just trying to get a handle around the size of the budget currently allocated to the Star Wars MMO and how that may differ in FY '11, and its impact in your P&L versus prior years?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you’d get to the answer to that, Ed, by the answer I can give you on the call. I think I can give you a couple of indicators though. At this point in time, there's a lot of different ways to calculate what's allocated to FY, say, '12 tit
componenttext: I don't know if you’d get to the answer to that, Ed, by the answer I can give you on the call. I think I can give you a couple of indicators though. At this point in time, there's a lot of different ways to calculate what's allocated to FY, say, '12 titles versus FY '11. Typically, the games label who’s got the longest lead on their title, so they'll have the highest percentage. They typically describe half or more of their budget for the fiscal year following as opposed to the fiscal year current. And it's a lesser percentage in both SPORTS, which builds annual sequels, and in the Play Label, which tends to build titles on shorter lead times. We have provided this indication which is very specific to what you're trying to learn now, which is we have a significant investment in our partnership MMO, the partnership we have with Lucas, it's a significant number. I really can't get into more than that. But I think you're going to have to use your best judgment from there.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can you just describe for a moment what the relationship is like in terms of how the revenue will be recognized by EA on the MMO?
componenttext: And can you just describe for a moment what the relationship is like in terms of how the revenue will be recognized by EA on the MMO?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Eric. We really can't get into it. I mean, we're obviously developing the core product and we operate the online services in terms of the distribution package because there's a -- that's still to be fully defined. We've clearly been investing in R
componenttext: This is Eric. We really can't get into it. I mean, we're obviously developing the core product and we operate the online services in terms of the distribution package because there's a -- that's still to be fully defined. We've clearly been investing in R&D for a number of years. I think the important point here is, as that title goes wide, and we're not giving any specific date, we'll move from a net OpEx investment mode to a highly-profitable Op income contributor. So it's a pretty important step-change when you compare a year with the MMO active versus the development stage that we're currently in this fiscal year.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on to Heath Terry with FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: Moving on to Heath Terry with FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the addition of the servers content network into Mass Effect 2. I know it's obviously way too early to tell what kind of impact that's going to have, but can you give us an idea of what you're expecting to see this kind of registration key b
componenttext: You mentioned the addition of the servers content network into Mass Effect 2. I know it's obviously way too early to tell what kind of impact that's going to have, but can you give us an idea of what you're expecting to see this kind of registration key built into the game? What kind of impact you're expecting to see that have on the market for that game as a used product, and whether or not there was any testing, focus grouping, whatever that you guys looked at that, or even past evidence with other games that gave you some sense of what kind of impact doing that would have for on sales of Mass Effect?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm glad you noticed. It was a strong and important strategic initiative to it for us. I would point out that we did things very similarly with The Sims 3. With Dragon Age: Origins, when we released it, we sort of initiated our approach here. Origin
componenttext: Well, I'm glad you noticed. It was a strong and important strategic initiative to it for us. I would point out that we did things very similarly with The Sims 3. With Dragon Age: Origins, when we released it, we sort of initiated our approach here. Originally, we have NBA Live with Dynamic DNA, almost a year and a half ago. In every case, what we’ve seen is a very positive response from the consumer and in each case, particularly starting with Dragon Age, a strong pick up in revenue per user. By and large, they like the extra content and we think it's a strong positive move. And as John mentioned in his prepared remarks, we've got similar kind of strong PDLC programs with each and every one of our titles this year. John, you want to add to that?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it speaks to our strategy of fewer bigger hits too, because consumers are buying top titles and playing them longer. And what is great about this content is not only is it a great incentive for consumers when they first buy the title, but it
componenttext: Yes, I think it speaks to our strategy of fewer bigger hits too, because consumers are buying top titles and playing them longer. And what is great about this content is not only is it a great incentive for consumers when they first buy the title, but it also teaches them and shows them that there's additional content online, and gets them used to that whole ecosystem and marketplace. So for instance, in Dragon Age: Origins, we had downloadable content in addition to the packed-in content, if you will, available for purchase on day one. And on the first week, we did over $1 million in sales on that title. So that's just the DLC obviously. So we're excited about DLC and to see there's another area for growth. And in fact, for fiscal 11, is up over 100% as we have said before. So we're bullish.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the attach rates too, are -- although it's early on, we think that the attach rate or usage is about 70% of overall units sold. So it's obviously much higher for those online registered users. So this indicates broad-based acceptance and usage by con
componenttext: Yes, the attach rates too, are -- although it's early on, we think that the attach rate or usage is about 70% of overall units sold. So it's obviously much higher for those online registered users. So this indicates broad-based acceptance and usage by consumers thus far.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to the point which we are getting at, it's also probably users that may not have bought the product originally.
componenttext: And to the point which we are getting at, it's also probably users that may not have bought the product originally.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Colin Sebastian with Lazard.
componenttext: Next question comes from Colin Sebastian with Lazard.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, I think you mentioned that Digital revenue streams are about a 20% non-GAAP operating margin level. And if I apply that to guidance, some $750 million of revenues, that leaves a pretty slim, maybe a low to mid single-digit margin of the Packaged Goo
componenttext: Eric, I think you mentioned that Digital revenue streams are about a 20% non-GAAP operating margin level. And if I apply that to guidance, some $750 million of revenues, that leaves a pretty slim, maybe a low to mid single-digit margin of the Packaged Goods business. So I want to clarify if that's the right way to think about the split? And then quickly on Playfish and the social networking games, I'm curious what your expectations are for performance of core brands like Madden that appeared to be planned for those platforms in the coming year?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of comments here. So to be very specific, we have a number of the different businesses that are aggregated in Digital. And I called out two larger-scale standalone or semi-standalone business units for POGO and Mobile. And those two specifically
componenttext: A couple of comments here. So to be very specific, we have a number of the different businesses that are aggregated in Digital. And I called out two larger-scale standalone or semi-standalone business units for POGO and Mobile. And those two specifically operate at 20% or better pro forma in non-GAAP operating margins. That's not to say though that every other line of business within the overall Digital portfolio is at 20%. So you can't take, 5 75 for this year or 7 50 for next year, times 20% necessarily. I think it's important to understand the profitability of these businesses if they get to critical mass. The second part of your question regards to Playfish. We're not going to specifically mention upcoming titles. But back when we announced the Playfish acquisition in November, we said quite clearly that one, we were acquiring a pre-existing, owned IP portfolio from a great set of developers. So we're expecting games from the Playfish team and we're also expecting to have them launch as our social game publishing arm more EA properties over time. And we don't have any specific titles to call out here, but we think that there's great synergy from our existing IP portfolio.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I would just add on to that, Eric, which is similar to what we saw with Mobile. So if you look at the top charts in Mobile these days, you'll see that the top games are mostly big, established brands. In fact, when you look at ours, mostly EA brands. S
componenttext: So I would just add on to that, Eric, which is similar to what we saw with Mobile. So if you look at the top charts in Mobile these days, you'll see that the top games are mostly big, established brands. In fact, when you look at ours, mostly EA brands. So we certainly think there's going to be a lot of room for creativity and innovation which Playfish leads the way in that space. And at the same time, we think that there's also opportunities to capitalize on some of our core brands. But Playfish folks are doing well. They just launched two new games, and Gangster City is doing great and excited to have them on board.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is John. I know you don't want one more answer to this, but I got to give you a perspective because I think, Colin, implicit in your question is a little bit about what kind of margin leverage is there in the business. And I think and I'd like to add
componenttext: This is John. I know you don't want one more answer to this, but I got to give you a perspective because I think, Colin, implicit in your question is a little bit about what kind of margin leverage is there in the business. And I think and I'd like to address that a little bit. So I think it's fair to say that the Packaged Goods business, absent breakout hits, is a single-digit margin business, at least the way they see it. When we study the business very carefully and look at we're investing in R&D frontline titles, we've got a great view of the industry because we see the cause of a lot of our partners, external developers with no corporate healthcare [ph] et cetera. And first observation is our costs are very competitive, it's not lower for like/unlike quality. The second thing is what's in this business for leverage? Our goal with few of the better is to drive to higher positions on the charts. And I'll give you two reference points. Same title plan, any one title breaking at an extra million and half units is about $0.10 EPS. So that's one title breaking can add about $0.10 in EPS. We're referring to like Need for Speed at its peak, that could be as much $0.30 to $0.40 EPS delta, given that it had done in the past as many as 4.5 million to 6 million units higher. And that's the key title we're driving to push up in the charts. Put another way, same title plan, one market share point, that's roughly $0.25 EPS. To give you a sense of the world we're working in, we think we've got our costs down tight. We think our cost per title is very competitive, and again, on the aggressively tight side of the equation, and what we're driving for now is using quality to drive leverage in the P&L by pushing it up further in the chart.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And next question comes from Andrey Glukhov with Brean Murray.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And next question comes from Andrey Glukhov with Brean Murray.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the pricing issue, especially in light of the fact that you guys are concentrating on bigger catch. What we've seen last year is, some of the retailers, particularly internationally, discounted even the top titles quite aggressively, which arguably pre
componenttext: On the pricing issue, especially in light of the fact that you guys are concentrating on bigger catch. What we've seen last year is, some of the retailers, particularly internationally, discounted even the top titles quite aggressively, which arguably pressures the value of the title in line of the consumer. Are you guys -- do you guys have any plans to moderate the behavior from some of your retail partners?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me come at this another way. I can't answer your question. So we can't describe our plans to moderate influence or adjust pricing on a pro forma future basis. We just can't go there. We're well advised on that front. What I would point you to if you w
componenttext: Let me come at this another way. I can't answer your question. So we can't describe our plans to moderate influence or adjust pricing on a pro forma future basis. We just can't go there. We're well advised on that front. What I would point you to if you want to understand this particular phenomenon better would be to compare of any sort of long-range top 10, top 20, top 30, you-pick-your-top range, and you will see the following things. You'll see that pricing is higher this cycle than last cycle. And compared to last cycle, retail pricing is holding at least as well as it did in the last cycle. If you actually study the individual press announcements, retail price announcements, promotions, et cetera, that were run by major retailers, you would see that we're probably getting to this lower pricing or the discounting you're referring to in a slightly different way than it happened in the last cycle. In the last cycle, which you saw by this point in the cycle, is frontline pricing for all that the biggest titles already break by $10. That hasn't happened in this cycle. What's happened in this cycle thus far is frontline pricing is holding, but then once it's in the market place, it's getting discounted more quickly than it did before. That's a slight difference in behavior. It can have -- I understand how that could make it look like there's ramp at discounting. But again, last cycle, what we saw was actually price reductions so there weren't as many discounts that took place against as price reductions. All in all, I think the analysis shows or the data shows that pricing's holding pretty well.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions about fourth quarter. It looks like some of your titles certainly are excelling well and maybe even exceeding your expectations. I guess what is still maybe missing your expectations or causing kind of an in-line or [indiscernible] of
componenttext: Couple of questions about fourth quarter. It looks like some of your titles certainly are excelling well and maybe even exceeding your expectations. I guess what is still maybe missing your expectations or causing kind of an in-line or [indiscernible] of the fourth quarter? And then secondly, on SPORTS, I know it's been a couple of year period where you're still seeing some units down on some of the key franchises, but is there anything you can do to kind of start growing the SPORTS business again? I know it's come up a lot with digital initiatives or other things to either grow the top or bottom line in total for the SPORTS, the key SPORTS franchises?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Eric, I'll take the first part of that question. Versus a month ago, when we gave our revised outlook, what we've seen happen is the following. We think that catalog revenue going into Q4 is a bit lower. Conversely, our expectations for the frontl
componenttext: This is Eric, I'll take the first part of that question. Versus a month ago, when we gave our revised outlook, what we've seen happen is the following. We think that catalog revenue going into Q4 is a bit lower. Conversely, our expectations for the frontline titles, those are really unchanged. We're feeling pretty good about frontline. So it's a catalog story in terms of revenue decrease, I mean, our expectations and more so, in Europe than North America. We also had a bit of adverse FX movement against some fazing differences Q3, Q4 in terms of operating expenses. And so, those would be the cost of change drivers on our current Q4 guidance versus what we had a month ago.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I might add just to quick pass to that before we get to the question about our SPORTS title, where I think I'll probably correct the presumption you've brought into the question. One of the things that sort of an interesting is we brought forward fairly h
componenttext: I might add just to quick pass to that before we get to the question about our SPORTS title, where I think I'll probably correct the presumption you've brought into the question. One of the things that sort of an interesting is we brought forward fairly high-profile marketing programs for both Mass Effect and for Dante. We advertise in both the AFC and FC Championship Games with the Mass Effect and we saw immediate response in terms of almost every metric we track. And as a perspective, those investments took about 50,000 units to break even. And while it's very difficult to point to a particular ad, break even against 50,000 units, given the strong results we saw with Mass Effect, seems like something that almost certainly occurred. We did a similar investment yesterday with Dante and we saw a similar spike, but it was our own internal metrics or metrics like where you stand on the charts on Amazon pre-orders. So some really good statistics to suggest these things are working well for us. And so with Eric's point, frontline feels pretty good in Q4. In terms of the SPORTS franchises, FIFA pre-digital is up sharply year-over-year. And Madden, as John indicated in his prepared comments, after starting weak, has continued to make progress week-to-week, virtually every week and it's up on the core consoles. We’ve seen a strong performance from NHL this year, and I would make that point sort of independent of Digital, which is adding to the totals and adding to the top line. So we feel pretty good about our SPORTS portfolio. One area where we want to see a pickup in the coming fiscal year, and we'll be talking about that at a later call, is an innovation we have across a range, and then in particular in NBA Live, where we'd like to make progress versus the competition.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, I would just add to SPORTS as well, Justin, that for next year, we are launching MMA, a new IP. We're taking EA SPORTS Active, which was wildly successful in the Wii in bringing that to multiple platforms. And, of course, we've got FIFA and Tiger Wo
componenttext: John, I would just add to SPORTS as well, Justin, that for next year, we are launching MMA, a new IP. We're taking EA SPORTS Active, which was wildly successful in the Wii in bringing that to multiple platforms. And, of course, we've got FIFA and Tiger Woods Online, both of which are new digital downloadable -- download play models on the Web. So I think we're doing a lot of innovation in the SPORTS area.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010

componenttext: And the next question comes from Arvind Bhatia with Sterne Agee.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Number one, I wanted to see if you can give us a sense of the incremental development cost for the motion controller in Arc that you’re experiencing right now, if it's meaningful? And then on the FIFA franchise, when you combine the two SKUs coming out,
componenttext: Number one, I wanted to see if you can give us a sense of the incremental development cost for the motion controller in Arc that you’re experiencing right now, if it's meaningful? And then on the FIFA franchise, when you combine the two SKUs coming out, I assume you're looking for growth in that franchises despite the stellar performance you had in '09? And my last question is on the Star Wars MMO. I know you don't want to get into too much detail, but can you give us some broad sense of the normalized operating margins at the company without that, so we can at least start to form some expectations beyond fiscal '11?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, why don't I start with the motion controller question which is how much incremental debt costs are the motion controllers costing us. And the reality is we have a pretty good lineup of motion-based games. So what it really affords us is an opportuni
componenttext: John, why don't I start with the motion controller question which is how much incremental debt costs are the motion controllers costing us. And the reality is we have a pretty good lineup of motion-based games. So what it really affords us is an opportunity to take that portfolio and look at the new motion controllers that other platforms are providing, and give us, frankly, debt cost amortization. So we don't see it as a big increase. In fact, we see that as a win in that respect.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And historically, FIFA, typically what ends up happening is, in a World Cup year, the World Cup SKUs that we ship are incremental. And we're on a roll with FIFA in our fiscal '10 product and we expect to continue to do really well there in fiscal '11. And
componenttext: And historically, FIFA, typically what ends up happening is, in a World Cup year, the World Cup SKUs that we ship are incremental. And we're on a roll with FIFA in our fiscal '10 product and we expect to continue to do really well there in fiscal '11. And then in terms of Star Wars, I agree with -- we may have been asked that similar question about trying to normal -- get a better grip inside that number. And we really don't think we can go further than we already have, which is a significant cost. MMOs can cost as much as 2x to 6x, 7x as much as a frontline title, if they're done right. It is a major investment for us. And as Eric had mentioned earlier, our goal is to reverse out, in the future, every bit that we've invested and then some.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just tie on another one then. On the breakout hit commentary you made, on how that can create operating leverage. Obviously, in fiscal '11, I'm just wondering, John, if you built in a certain number of breakout hits or have you -- I mean, like how
componenttext: Let me just tie on another one then. On the breakout hit commentary you made, on how that can create operating leverage. Obviously, in fiscal '11, I'm just wondering, John, if you built in a certain number of breakout hits or have you -- I mean, like how should we think about the expectations you have for the various titles? Are they one or two breakout hit models or just -- or is everything just kind of middle of the range and then, you're hoping for upside to those?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a difficult question to ask like how conservative or how aggressive your judgments are. I think as a starting point, we're probably at the lower end of the range for what most people are going to guide to for packaged goods sector performance i
componenttext: Well, it's a difficult question to ask like how conservative or how aggressive your judgments are. I think as a starting point, we're probably at the lower end of the range for what most people are going to guide to for packaged goods sector performance in calendar '10. Our minus three result though is probably not inconsistent with what's going to happen in January. So at least in January, where we've indicated -- but yes, there's 11 months to go and the lion's share is going to take place in the fall. As I think we mentioned, we see some titles have the potential for breakout. My way of thinking about it is, on a label-by-label basis, SPORTS has got net plus titles year-over-year in the form of MMA, and a broader base on Active against platforms. The game's label sort of swaps one title for another, it's neither up nor down on a 12-month basis in terms of its title slate. And The Sims label, basically, swaps out on console for PC lunch at the highest level. Yes, we loss one movie title in the form of G.I. Joe. That was a relatively modest performer for us in this past fiscal year. And we're adding a multi-platform MySims title and then a second Sims title in the year. So when we look at that portfolio, we've guided that to be flat. If there are significant breakouts, we would see market share growth, but we haven't assumed that in our model. And if I were to point to things that I think have potential to break out, that are not counting on as breakouts, that would include sort of Medal of Honor, Crysis, Sims console and perhaps a few other titles. I'm really bullish about Dead Space 2 in the fourth quarter.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And catalog sales from Mass Effect and Battlefield: Bad Company.
componenttext: And catalog sales from Mass Effect and Battlefield: Bad Company.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in the first part of the year.
componenttext: Yes, in the first part of the year.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could, I'd like to respond to a question about how was the SPORTS label doing year-over-year. So starting with FY '09, comparing that to FY '10, the SPORTS label were all as up significantly. You've got key drivers like the launch of EA SPORTS Active
componenttext: If I could, I'd like to respond to a question about how was the SPORTS label doing year-over-year. So starting with FY '09, comparing that to FY '10, the SPORTS label were all as up significantly. You've got key drivers like the launch of EA SPORTS Active. The tremendous performance by FIFA. The packaged goods as well as the digital extensions. And so that's very significant growth '10 versus fiscal '09. And in fiscal '11, we're expecting continued growth as well in the overall SPORTS label.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from John Taylor of Arcadia Investments.
componenttext: And the next question comes from John Taylor of Arcadia Investments.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you might be able to characterize the additional revenue potential that you're looking at from the follow-on digital content and maybe talk about it within the silos or the baskets in terms of SPORTS and EA games and so on. How much additional
componenttext: I wonder if you might be able to characterize the additional revenue potential that you're looking at from the follow-on digital content and maybe talk about it within the silos or the baskets in terms of SPORTS and EA games and so on. How much additional can you get over what period of time and maybe can you give us a sense of what kind of lags or increased revenue per user? And maybe even put that within the context -- the answer that you gave at the beginning of the call about the consoles being used is one thing. I mean, time is one thing, but they're being used for an awful lot of other things, and none of the video games guys are getting much revenue, also some net sites [ph] being downstream, TSM for instance. So what I'm trying to get at is how you compensate for that, and maybe talk about that within that ARPU context?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: The data that I gave you on console usage was not whether they were turned on or off, it's whether they were being used to play games. So the data was narrow enough to sort of capture the flavor we were trying to talk to. The second point is, and this is
componenttext: The data that I gave you on console usage was not whether they were turned on or off, it's whether they were being used to play games. So the data was narrow enough to sort of capture the flavor we were trying to talk to. The second point is, and this is something that might be fun to look at, I often like to look at things over a longer period. And just the last week of the month or quarter, '03 to '09, I think if you're just to pick a cycle as opposed to [ph] we are now, the top three in top 30 are 2x if not 3x larger in the business. So a few of it better [ph] is designed to finish further up in those charts and benefit from that. And lastly, I think it's really early on in this Q to give you a revenue for downloadable content across the full range of our products. But I will give you these indicators. In many cases, the number can be double digits, like north of $10. But those are typically isolated circumstances where that occurs with a game. Across the weighted average of our portfolio, I would like to see it to get to that. But it's certainly nowhere near that on our FY '11 model. It's in that $2 range. That's a gigantic pickup from zero. That is essentially brand new ARPU, and it's part of our digital growth story. I see lots of reasons to believe that will move north over time. And as I was trying to say, it could have been in a broad or many way how people can interpret or misinterpret the packaged goods business. I would say EA strategy is fewer but bigger and higher ARPU. Two of it, bigger drives revenue per title at the retail level and/or download, if that model develops more fully over time. In all the PDLC and stuff that we get on the back end, that's ARPU against each desk [ph]. And so that's what we're seeking to do. We think it's a smart investment pieces for us, given the way the industry is evolving.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can I ask -- on the 7 50 or whatever the digital piece is going to be. Could you give us a rough geographic breakdown on what that might look like?
componenttext: And can I ask -- on the 7 50 or whatever the digital piece is going to be. Could you give us a rough geographic breakdown on what that might look like?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now it's more then North America than international. But we're not going to specify [ph] the geo. So would note that it's in terms of the growth, the online services we have in Asia have been quite successful to date. So FIFA Online is going in Korea. We'
componenttext: Now it's more then North America than international. But we're not going to specify [ph] the geo. So would note that it's in terms of the growth, the online services we have in Asia have been quite successful to date. So FIFA Online is going in Korea. We're extending that online services product across portions of the regions. So there is that growth there. The highest growth rate that we see within the Digital portfolio is for the console PDLC. And so we’ve seen success today at across products like FIFA, which sell principally in Europe, but obviously, in North America as well and Asia. Madden, Mass Effect and Dragon Age, we're expecting that our overall console PDLC business to grow by over 100% in fiscal '11 versus fiscal '10, and that may have a revenue distribution that, more or less, mirrors the underlying packaged goods. But it could deviate a bit.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that question will come from Jeetil Patel with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And that question will come from Jeetil Patel with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, I guess if you look at the fiscal '11, what type of visibility do you have into kind of the $0.50 to $0.70 EPS number? I guess relative to years past, I guess would you say there's more or less or comparable amounts of visibility into kind o
componenttext: First of all, I guess if you look at the fiscal '11, what type of visibility do you have into kind of the $0.50 to $0.70 EPS number? I guess relative to years past, I guess would you say there's more or less or comparable amounts of visibility into kind of how this year plays out relative to, I guess, how you saw the last couple of years play out? Second, I guess going back to Colin's question, but if you back out the profitability of the Mobile business and also the Distribution business, we end up with a core publishing operating margin of about 5%. I guess within that number, is the bigger theme or kind of issue that it's the core EA business on the SPORT side and core products that you've had for years that's underperforming or where the margins are depressed? Or is it actually more on the newer IP that you've got coming out this year that or, in general, that seems to be where the margin drag is?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of thoughts. The first one shows a visibility, an observation about F '10. And we, too, are disappointed with the F '10 results. We guided at the beginning of F '10, the 7% top-line growth for the sector, and it ended up being roughly minus 10, 1
componenttext: A couple of thoughts. The first one shows a visibility, an observation about F '10. And we, too, are disappointed with the F '10 results. We guided at the beginning of F '10, the 7% top-line growth for the sector, and it ended up being roughly minus 10, 17-point split. And our most recent guidance for the fiscal year versus original was 4 3 and we're 4 1 in our most recent guidance. So we're adhering top line much, much better than the sector overall, which is reflective in the fact that our fiscal year-to-date market shares are up and projected to be up through the fiscal year. I would say that our biggest challenge on visibility in fiscal '10 was at the sector level. We've pretty much charted where we thought. Our expenses came in as we thought. Our business performed at the market share level as we thought. We delivered the titles that we said we would deliver with extreme fidelity. What we missed was the top line, which was driven primarily by factors related to the sector. And for what its worth, even making up half the revenue forecast loss at the sector level. And having that play in the EA, we would have made our plans. So it's a tough one. So it's a tough one. I don't know that we were alone in forecasting the industry off in calendar year '09. It was a very frustrating and challenging experience for us. As we look into fiscal '10, I only hope that we're as accurate as we have been on our title slip versus non-title slips, the quality of our games, the windows that we had in the market share that we achieved because we nailed it with almost perfect accuracy in '09. So the key question for me is more about the sector level. At this point, we think minus three is the best assumption going in. We also noted that we're sensitive to that assumption. 5%, neither direction is a little bit North of $0.20. So it's a very, very important assumption for us. By the way, it's about the same for -- impact is a one share, one market share point. In terms of the 5%, what's underperforming or over performing in the packaged goods portfolio, what we've gotten to now is 36 major titles. I think if you did sort of a study of our business until you got major breakout hits, that makes up a significant portion of your portfolio, single-digit returns is fairly typical. On pure Packaged Goods businesses, it has -- and our goal this year is to break out and drive above that. We've identified in quarters past and years past that our biggest deficit coming out of the fiscal -- for the fiscal '04, '05 console transition was that we basically had lost Lord of the Rings, Bond, Medal of Honor and we were down on Need for Speed. And where we're going now is we're replacing that with Dragon Age, Mass Effect, back the Medal of Honor, growth on Need for Speed. So our goal is to replace that and get back in the double-digit strongly. We're not guiding to it because we're waiting for it to happen first.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up, didn't you, at the beginning of fiscal '10 guide to about 4 billion, so your revenue stayed about the same from the beginning of the year to the end of the year, didn't they?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: We guided to 4 3. And so, no. We missed on top line. Not as much as the sector miss, but we missed. And I think we detailed our rationale for what it occurred there. Some margin shift as a consequence of more digital titles and a revenue miss, which I thi
componenttext: We guided to 4 3. And so, no. We missed on top line. Not as much as the sector miss, but we missed. And I think we detailed our rationale for what it occurred there. Some margin shift as a consequence of more digital titles and a revenue miss, which I think is consistent but not as rich a miss as the sector overall. Thanks very much for the call. And we'll see you next time.
